ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about what different religious and philosophical traditions define as a life worth living, and I was able to reflect a lot on my own values and beliefs for what a meaningful life looks like for me.

This class was all about reflection and learning about beliefs found throughout the world. We read texts and papers analyzing groups who believe certain things such as a religion, to see how it contributes to a good life.
We learned about  and discussed the different elements that constitute a life worth living under different traditions.

I learned so much about many different perspectives on the life worth living, and was presented with material that challenged my own assumptions about the life worth living, which I loved. I come out of this course with real-world applications of the things I learned through both my values and behavior, and for that I am so grateful!
I developed a greater appreciation of other traditions.
different philosophies from religion and literature about what makes a life worth living, and what values to strive towards
Introduction to various philosophical works and theories about the good life.
I learned a lot about the different world views of different cultures and religions around the world.
I learned about different religions and schools of thought, and some of their applications to my life. We discussed parts of Christianity, Buddhism, Judiasm, Utilitarianism, and other belief systems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were interesting and thought-provoking, and I think we spanned a good number of different traditions without turning into a survey course. Our discussions took place in both the larger room and in breakout rooms, and those were always great opportunities to share our own thoughts while hearing other people's interpretations of the readings and what stood out to them. Our discussions really helped me consider different perspectives and reflect on my own values. The course really pushed me to think about why I believe certain things or why I prioritize and do certain things in my life, and I am so grateful for that. The only weakness would be that there were too many interesting points in the readings and overarching units and we sometimes didn't get to discuss things as fully as we would have hoped. Good problem for a class to have though!

Out of all the courses I have taken at Yale, I enjoyed this one the most. The usage of Facebook posts, lots of small breakout room discussions, and talks with the professor allowed me to be most attentive and thoroughly enjoy my class.
Discussion did not flow very well in seminar, broken up by a lot of opinions by the prof. I really enjoyed the readings though!
only strengths!! i loved learning about various philosophies of life, and many of the ideas we learned will really stay with me in future years

The class was very laid back which was nice. It felt like a comfortable space to reflect on our ideas, which seems to stand out from the stress of other Yale classes.

I'm not sure I really got a handle for some of the religions we studied.

I really enjoyed the breakout rooms in this class. In many of the other zoom breakout rooms that I've been in, the goal is to solve a problem or come up with an answer to some question. I liked how much I was able to reflect in these breakout rooms and in the larger group discussions.

The syllabus for the course seems to use different schools of thought to help students find out what their visions of a life worth living are. However, I feel like the readings on the syllabus were more fit for a survey course on world religions. While some readings were interesting, others just gave background information about the belief we were talking about (like the Islam readings). It might benefit the course to update the readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly, even though I did may have gotten a different experience this year online, this class was taught really well online. Two seminars a week, where my class enjoyed talking to each other, and my teacher brought energy every morning made me enjoy the class. She used the features of zoom really well, incorporating the breakout rooms, polls, and chat every class.
Typical virtual seminar format.
virtual class kept everything safe! live zoom allowed for lively discussions with peers
The discussion format and breakout rooms were good ways of facilitating discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ABSOLUTELY! I heard so many wonderful things about the course and I can confirm that this course is so worthwhile and such a meaningful thing to incorporate into anyone's education. I think having structured self-reflection times and spaces was very important to me, especially since I'm graduating, and this class gave me so much more than just a space to reflect. It gave me a clearer vision of what I want my life to look like and what steps I can take to achieve that vision.
Yes, it is a therapeutic class, that was not very stressful. You will enjoy coming to class to learn about a range of topics, all of which can add to a life worth living.
Yes, please take this if you can get a spot! It's a great way to not only engage with the material, but also discuss these questions with your peers.
The readings are really interesting and the workload is low (3 short papers). Why not?
yes! new ideas taught in the class will help me to keep my values at the forefront in everyday life!
If they are looking for a relaxed class to begin learning about philosophy.

If you want to learn more about what the good life means to other peoples and cultures, I'd definitely recommend this class. You get to reflect a lot about how these views align with your own and may even change your mind on certain things.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Just virtual seminar, and occasional 1-1 paper meetings.
None
